title: Feature: The Music From Skins (S6, E1)
content:
Love it or hate it, Skins is back on our TV sets.

So it’s hugely cliched, overly offensive and features some of the worst acting ever seen, but I can’t help having a soft spot for it. Earlier this evening the first episode of series six of the BAFTA award winning drama was premiered on E4, so with CitR being a music website, it makes sense to look back upon the musical offerings used in the show.

Opening moped scene – Azealia Banks – 212 (Feat. Lazy Jay)

The most hyped track of the past few months was inevitably going to appear on the show at some point, but including it in the opening credits was a bold move. Did it work? Well yeah, just about.

On the drive to the villa – The War On Drugs – Baby Missiles

A modern day classic and perfectly fitting to the jovial mood of the scene, an inspired choice.

Lounging by the pool – Hanni El Khatib – Build. Destroy. Rebuild.

Another good choice, although could have used slightly more of the track.

Matty and Frankie arrive – The Smiths – How Soon Is Now?

So it appears that Joey Barton has made The Smiths cooler than ever, however including How Soon Is Now? wasn’t the best move, and was only made worse by the horrendous Morrissey name-drop later in the script.

The boys have a shower – H-Kayne – Issawa Style

Soundtracking the ‘funny’ moments is never easy, but this inclusion of a relatively obscure Moroccan rap hit was another fine pick.

Rich and Grace on the roof – King Creosote & Jon Hopkins – Your Own Spell

The highlight from one of last years most underrated records, this track deserved a far more poignant moment, not helped by the rigid acting.

Grace sings – Francoise Hardy – All Because Of You (performed by Jessica Sula)

A fantastic song unfortunately ruined by a fairly average cover. I get that they were going for the ‘unique’ and touching element, but this just didn’t work at all.

Party at Luke’s – Segal – Trainjek Nostril

Worked superbly, and hey, at least it’s not Skrillex, right? I bet the cool kids loved the drop.

Trainjek Nostril (Nostril) by Segal

Luke and Frankie dance – Nick – Morocco’s Festival (Simon & Shaker Teramik Remix)

Another dance number, not quite as fitting as the previous track and fell rather flat, in what could have been a scene of high sexual tension.

The morning after – Dark Dark Dark – Wild Goose Chase

A truly beautiful track that again could have been used to more emotionally driven effect. Nonetheless, a stellar inclusion.

Rich and Grace on the rooftop – Sporto Kantès – Slits

An interesting choice that just about worked, despite the scene in question being a dud.

Poolside – Icarus – Police Academy 6 (Feat. unouomedude)

Great to see one of my favourite artists getting high profile recognition, and hopefully the inclusion of this track will open even more people up to the unforgettable music of unouomedude.

Police Academy 6 – Icarus (featuring unouomedude) – 2011 by AMDISCS

Beach Party – Adeptus – Copacliasexicalla

I don’t believe this track is available to hear on the internet yet, but it fitted in rather nicely, alongside three tracks from Segal – Look Up, Temper and Forbidden Bells.

Liv finds out Luke is no good – Tim Hecker – Chimeras

What can I say, the man is a legend. Chimeras perfectly matched the mood of the scene.

Car chase – Venetian Snares – Hand Throw

Heavy and rather fitting for the best scene of the episode.

Nick in college – Scott Matthews – Eyes Wider Than Before

Another classic, this time used at exactly the right moment.

Check back next week for another round up of the music used in Episode 2.
